Headline: Olympic venues revisited
Article_Body: Olympic heritage: Barcelona cemented itself as a must-visit tourist destination after the Spanish city hosted the Olympics in 1992. Pictured here: British diver Tracey Miles silhouetted against the city's famous skyline. Disused spots: Other cities have more complex Olympic legacies -- Athens hosted the Games in 2004, but some of the venues are now abandoned. Nature takes over: In China, some of Beijing's 2008 Olympic venues have been overrun by nature. Ongoing project: The International Olympic Committee is currently conducting a study looking at the post-Games use of all current Olympic venues, including Athens, pictured here. Results are due in early 2021. Tourism legacy: The Olympics is often cited as helping boost a city's tourism --  whether it actually does or not is debated by experts. Pictured here: an American tourist at the Beijing Olympic Games in 2008. London 2012: London's Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park was intended to be future-proof with venues that would serve the local community long after the Games. Adapting for the future: The London Aquatics Centre hosted swimming events in 2012, and has since been adapted into a public pool, that occasionally hosts big events. Double act: The ArcelorMittal Orbit tower -- a controversial piece of public art built for the Olympics, now doubles up as a slide and viewing platform.
